title-group.article-title: Preparation and mechanical properties of SiO2f/BN composites with quasi-sandwich structure for wave transparency

abstract.p: Silica fibers reinforced boron nitride composites with a quasi-sandwich structure for high-temperature wave transparency were fabricated by precursor infiltration pyrolysis technology. The loading capacity of the quasi-sandwich structure is close to that of the solid samples as theoretically calculated, in addition to showing enhanced electrical properties and lower density. The test results for the mechanical properties are basically consistent with the theoretical values. The bending strength of the longitudinal and latitudinal I-shaped samples was 74% and 69% that of the solid sample. The fracture behavior of longitudinal and latitudinal I-shaped samples was also investigated by using compression testing. There are two types of fracture behaviors, which vary with the weaving direction. In the case of longitudinal samples, solid and I-shaped samples share a similar fracture appearance, while the latitudinal ones show crack expansion in the opposite direction between the solid and I-shaped samples. The dielectric constant of the quasi-sandwich is much lower than that in the solid samples, which is very beneficial in terms of the wave-transparent properties of structures such as radomes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the development of antenna technologies, broadband frequency antennae have been used to enhance the capacity of vehicles. A radome is always placed in front of the vehicle to protect the antenna system from damage due to wind and rain.1,2 Generally, the frequency often ranges from 2 to 18 GHz or even broader. Sandwich construction, which consists of two dense dielectric skins separated by a porous core with a lower relative dielectric constant than the skins,1 is usually used in the structural design of radomes in order to fulfill the requirements for broadband application. So far, sandwich structures generally utilize electrically thin plastic skins and cores made of a fiberglass or phenolic honeycomb, or else a lightweight plastic foam material.3 However, the poor performance of these structures at high temperature limits their use in hypersonic vehicle.3

Continuous fiber reinforced ceramic matrix composites (CMCs), which possess superior functions that integrate both mechanical and dielectric properties, have spawned growing utilization in the radome field.2 Due to the superior dielectric and high-temperature mechanical properties (3000℃), boron nitride (BN) ceramics in particular become the most promising wave-transparent materials. Furthermore, BN ceramics, which are synthesized by pyrolysis of borazine at a relatively low temperature of about 1000℃,4 maintain stable mechanical and dielectric properties over a wide range of temperatures.5 Thus, it is hoped that continuous SiO2 fibers reinforced BN composite (SiO2f/BN) sandwich structures by the precursor infiltration pyrolysis (PIP) method can be fabricated. However, because of weak binding forces between layers, the traditional sandwich structure could not be realized in condition.6 By using a new weaving technology followed by PIP, a SiO2f/BN quasi-sandwich structure is reported in this paper, and the practical and theoretical mechanical and electrical properties of the composites were investigated. The fracture behavior of this new structure is shown as well.

sec.title: Experimental procedures
sec.p:
Silica fibers with a purity of 99.95 wt% and a tensile strength of 1.7 GPa were provided by Jingzhou Feilihua Quartz Glass Corporation. A model of a quasi-sandwich structure, together with a 2.5-dimensional preform, produced by Beijing Fiberglass Research and Design Institute, is shown in Figure 1. The preform is woven of silica fibers with 2.5 dimensions with the assistance of a steel mold. In the preform, the fiber volume fraction is 45%. The steel mold used was primarily to form a rectangular cuboid space in the woven material. The unit structure of the 2.5-dimensional woven material includes longitudinal yards, latitudinal yards and thickness direction yards. The longitudinal yards direction parallel with the rectangular cuboid space either length direction or wide direction, and then the latitudinal yards direction parallel with the cuboid space either wide direction or length direction, and the thickness direction yards direction parallel with the rectangular cuboid space thickness direction. In general, a sandwich structure is a porous board covered on both sides by two dense boards. In this study, the composites include many regular parallel rectangular cuboid spaces, so the equivalent density in the middle is much lower than that on both sides. Therefore, the structure is called a quasi-sandwich. Figure 1.
A model of quasi-sandwich structure.

Borazine, the precursor of a BN ceramic matrix, is a transparent liquid with a density of 0.8 g/cm3, very low viscosity and a high ceramic yield (≥90 wt%). The SiO2f/BN composites with a quasi-sandwich structure were prepared according to the following stages. The silica fiber was subjected to a pretreatment process to remove the organic impurities from the surface. This pretreatment process consisted of heating the fiber in air at 600℃ for 1 h. The preform, together with the mold, was then infiltrated with borazine in vacuum. The borazine-infiltrated preform and mold were cured at 70℃ for 6 h, 80℃ for 4 h and 90℃ for 2 h in an inert atmosphere, followed by pyrolysis in a nitrogen atmosphere at 900℃ for 2 h. In order to densify the composites, the steps from the borazine infiltration, curing and pyrolysis were repeated for five times. In the composites with the quasi-sandwich structure, the SiO2 fibers act as reinforcement to enhance tensile strength and toughness in the BN matrix.

Because of the irregular structure, the mechanical properties of a quasi-sandwich structure can be characterized as a comparison of the flexural strength of an I-shaped sample with that of solid samples, as shown in Figure 2. The samples were prepared by cutting the quasi-sandwich structure composites in different directions and different parts, as shown in Figure 2. In consideration of the longitudinal and latitudinal directions of the composites, the solid and I-shaped samples with the longitudinal directions are denoted as “lo-S” and “lo-I”. For example, in the longitudinal direction parallel with the cuboid space length direction, a “lo-S” sample can be obtained by cutting Line 1, and a “lo-I” sample can be obtained by cutting Lines 2 and 3. This same method is used for the samples cut in the latitudinal directions, which are denoted as “la-S” and “la-I”. The flexural strength of the composites was determined on a WDW-100 computer-controlled universal testing machine with a span of 60 mm and crosshead speed of 0.5 mm/min carried out on a test piece 10 mm wide and 8 mm thick. The dielectric properties were examined by the short-cutting waveguide method with a specimen dimension of 15.8 × 7.9 × (5–10) mm. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out on a Bruker Advanced D8 diffractometer at 10°min−1 with a 0.02 s−1 sampling rate.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
It is reasonable that the elements of matrix are not more than B, N and H since the precursor of matrix is borazine. Figure 3 shows the XRD pattern of the SiO2f/BN composites. The broad peaks around 20–30° and 40–45° are identified as amorphous BN ceramic since h-BN XRD peaks locates at 26.2° (002) and 42.8° (100), and silica fibers are in glass phase. Based on reports7 BN ceramics exhibit high compressive strength of 120–150 MPa and bending strength of about 50 MPa within the temperature interval from 20 to 1400–1500℃ and stable dielectric properties. Thus, the BN-based composites are promising materials for wave transparency materials at high temperature. Figure 3.
X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the silica fibers reinforced boron nitride (SiO2f/BN) composites.

Photographs of the silica fiber-reinforced boron nitride composites with a quasi-sandwich structure and their models are shown in Figure 2. As shown in the model Małgorzata Kramkowska, the quasi-sandwich structure samples can be assumed to be simply equal to the I-shaped sample due to the similar force experienced between the two.8 The quasi-sandwich structure samples with 2.5-D performance were prepared with longitudinal and latitudinal directions, as clearly shown in Figure 4. Regardless of the orientation of the prepared products, no defects, such as delamination or cracks, were observed after PIP, although thermal mismatch stress occurs due to the different properties of the composites.9 These results indicate that a good packing structure is obtained by the PIP process. Figure 4.
Specimens of silica fibers reinforced boron nitride (SiO2f/BN) composites quasi-sandwich (a) surface and (b) cross section.

In equation (3), M is the bending moment, which is equal to a quarter of the product between the bending load P and span S, and Iz is the inertia of cross-section of the I-shaped beam along the z axis.

The two different structures with the same material and the cross section are illustrated in Figure 5. The bending stress can be chosen to 100 MPa, so as to calculate the load capacity of the two structures by using equations (3) and (4), respectively. Then, the mechanical properties of quasi-sandwich structure are successfully evaluated. The bending load P1 of the solid sample (shown in Figure 5) can be calculated using equation (1). The bending load P2 of the beam (shown in Figure 5) can be calculated using equation (3). For the solid sample, σb = 100 MPa, B = 10 mm, H = 8 mm and S = 60 mm. For the beam, σb = 100 MPa, B = 10 mm, H = 8 mm, b = 3 mm, h = 5 mm, S = 60 mm and M = (P2 × S)/4. The calculated results then give P1 = 711.1 N, P2 = 589.6 N. Comparing the load capacity of the solid sample with that of the beam, P2/P1 = 0.83. The load capacity of the I-shaped sample does not show much decrease, which mainly contributes to the uniform cross section with relatively high inertia.

Accordingly, the ratio of P2 to P1 (P2/P1) is 0.83. Then, the ratio of the corresponding bending stress σ2 and σ1 is 0.83. That is to say, the measured values of the mechanical properties of the quasi-sandwich structure, to some extent, are lower than those of the theoretical ones. On the one hand, the theoretical values obtained are based on materials with an isotropic structure. The samples, however, are woven fibers and their mechanical properties in the two directions, shown in Table 1, are apparently different. So how the fibers are woven has a certain impact on the mechanical properties of the composites. On the other hand, certain dispersion exists in the mechanical properties of ceramic matrix composite. Besides, the repeated processing cycles Małgorzata Kramkowska may result in mechanical damage to the fibers which, therefore, can affect the mechanical properties of the composites.

It can be seen that the bending strength of the samples perpendicular to the rib exhibits very similar properties with the theoretical ones, which demonstrates that the skins of the quasi-sandwich structure mainly suffer loading, and the ribs have little ability to bear loading. So it is critical to fabricate denser dielectric skins separated by a less dense core with a honeycomb structure, as shown in Figure 2.

The appearance of the failed lo-S, lo-I, la-S and la-I samples is shown in Figure 6. Bearing bending loads, the upper surface of the lo-S samples suffer from pressure stress and the bottom bears tensile stress. Because of the higher tensile strength in 2.5-D woven fiber-reinforced composites, the failure first happens in the bottom and then the woven fibers begin to bear load, which gives rise to cracks propagating to the upper surface.15–17 With the increasing load, the fiber fractures and absorbs a significant amount of fracture energy from the composites and thus brings out the failure of the composites in the end. The expansion direction of the crack inclines at about 45° from the sample’s axis. The fracture behavior of the la-S samples is almost the same as that with the lo-S. However, the crack growth, as shown in Figure 6, develops on the outer surface and propagates to the interior perpendicular to the sample’s axis. Figure 6.
Fracture appearances of the silica fibers reinforced boron nitride (SiO2f/BN) composites: (a) lo-S; (b) la-S; (c) lo-I; and (d) la-I.

Moreover, the fracture behavior of the lo-S samples is similar to that of the lo-I samples exhibited in Figure 6. However, cracks in the la-I samples extend along the axis, which is the opposite of what occurs with the la-S samples. That is because in a la-I sample, the width of b (shown in Figure 5) is only 3 mm. Thus, the interface would break down along the latitudinal direction under the shearing force.

The load–displacement curves after the maximum value in a ceramic matrix composite is strongly dependent on the nature of the fiber/matrix interface and microstructure. The interfacial bonding strength can be evaluated by the morphology of fracture surfaces. Extensive fiber pull-out indicates relatively weak fiber/matrix interfacial bonding, whereas little fiber pull-out and short pull-out length indicates strong fiber/matrix interfacial bonding. The load–displacement curves and scanning electron microscope (SEM) photos of SiO2f/BN composites are illustrated in Figures 7 and 8, respectively. Figure 7 indicates typical rough ruptures, which is proven by the composites fracture surfaces in Figure 8. The relatively weak interfacial bonding and the energy absorbing by fiber pull-out contributed to high mechanical properties, including the longitude flexural strength and modulus. Figure 7.

The dielectric constant and loss tangent are crucial for wave transparency materials. The wave-transparent materials for radomes must be of low dielectric constant and loss tangent to minimize the wave energy reflection and absorption. Lower dielectric constant is beneficial to wave-transparent properties of materials such as higher wave-transmittance and lower pointing error. Obviously, the equivalent dielectric constants of the quasi-sandwich are much lower than the 2.37 of the SiO2f/BN composites. Thus, the composites are very similar to the sandwich not only in structure, porous inside and dense outside, but also in dielectric property, exhibiting low dielectric constants inside and high dielectric constants outside. Thus, it is hoped that a structure derived from the quasi-sandwich such as a radome will exhibit better wave-transparent properties, which will be reported in later papers.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
SiO2f/BN composites with the quasi-sandwich structure were fabricated by the PIP process. The properties are as follows:
The load capacity of the I-shaped sample is 83% of an ordinary solid sample. The bending strength of longitude and latitude I-shaped samples are 74% and 69%, respectively, of ordinary solid samples.
In the case of longitudinal samples, solid and I-shaped samples share similar fracture appearance, with the expansion direction of the crack inclined about 45° from the axis of sample. Latitudinal samples show crack expansion in the opposite direction between solid and I-shaped samples.
The dielectric constant of the quasi-sandwich was calculated to be approximately 1.21–1.39, which is very beneficial to wave-transparent properties of the structures such as radomes.
